newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil '96 external financing was 2.0 pct/GDP.
newsitem.headline: Brazil '96 external financing was 2.0 pct/GDP.

text.p: Brazil's external accounts financing needs in 1996 were $14.91 billion, equivalent to 2.0 percent of gross domestic product, and easily financed by overseas borrowing and short-term capital inflows, a Central Bank official said.

Altamir Lopes, head of the bank's economics department, said 1996's $24.3 billion current account gap was partially financed by record net foreign direct investment of $9.442 billion, which covered 38.8 percent of the total. The remainder was financed abroad.
In 1995, Brazil's external financing needs were equivalent to 1.92 percent of GPD.
"(The balance) is being financed by debt and short-term capital flows," Lopes told reporters, adding that "2.0 percent (of GDP financing needs) are not high."
Total foreign capital inflows in 1996 were $79.007 billion versus $53.885 billion in 1995, the Central Bank said in a statement.

Short-term portfolio investment accounted for $24.684 billion, of which $18.566 billion flowed straight back out. In 1995, portfolio investment flows amounted to $22.559 billion, with $17.806 billion in outflows.

Foreign borrowing by Brazilian firms and the government rose to $28.09 billion in 1996 from $15.88 billion in 1995. Lopes said the quality of Brazilian overseas borrowing increased steadily during 1996.
The total foreign borrowing figure includes commercial paper, securitizations, debt rollover, leasing agreements, anticipated export payments and other items.
There were 366 bond issues abroad in 1996 totalling $21.6 billion versus 258 and $14.3 billion the year before.

Average maturities rose to 7.7 years in fourth quarter 1996 from 6.2 years in the same year-before period and average spreads narrowed to 407 basis points over U.S. Treasuries from 517 bps over, Lopes said.
Debt issues by the private financial sector actually fell in 1996, but the number of placements by the commercial and industrial sector jumped to 243 from 119 in 1995.
